447. Darley (Mrs. William R.)
Dear Sir:

I am writing to express my regret that the guest-
ionnaire has not been answered until this
late date. The illness and consequent
preparing my mother (Mrs. August Stearns)
for her 75th birthday have prevented me from doing
so. I have been unable to attend to this task due to
my mother's health and their living
in West Virginia where there is no
telephonic communication.

Yours sincerely,

(Mary) R. Darley

Mother and Father were born in
Maryland - August Stearns in
County Wellington - 12 miles south
of Wellsboro and their parents were
from Pennsylvania. They married in
Maryland and lived in
Pennsylvania in a small town called
Darbyville. She died at age 48.
Dear Sirs:

I have with regret that the guest-
cuisine has not been answered until this
late date — The illness & consequent
prolonging illness (Mrs. Augusta Stewart)
in Feb. I have been principal reason for delay.

With so many other matters that I have
attempted to give our building & their dinner
invitations — I fear so there's that feveration
have had a worse than ill-understanding history.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Dad came out in 1890 & looked things over -- they were back ready to relate his building brothers' friends family regarding his idea with a great deal's skepticism. The Indians at that time presented a generous picture indeed. They were regarded as well in the ship.

A brother tried receiving machinery & two railroad cars. Co. Y & Va. (side board) added new cars have been relegated to barnwood.

They spent the first spring & summer 1891 with Dad's two sons in the present Spring Brook district ½ way between South Smith & Appleton.

Mother was all happy over their setup over prospect & work. They rented a farm. It was an old farm that their forebear came by. It was dragged down when riding a pony - presently they bought the present farm June 17-14-1893. It was a log house, very warm & cool. Later they added to it - with frame rooms because Dad raising that when handling the lumber farm. He got some lumber in it - & they are good here - totally generation lower than our ancestors.
Dad came out in 1890's looking things over - his friends & family seemed to relate his feelings towards their friends & family regarding the idea with a great deal of skepticism - the Indians at that time presented a fascinating picture indeed.

They were both regarded as animals in their own right.

A brother died - leaving two children - two nieces - now have been relegated to board school.

They speak the first spring & summer 1891 with Doug's wife & his family in the present Spring Brook district 1/2 way between South Smith & Appleton.

Mother was still all happy over their setup near prospect - & wish it. They rented a farm - & was our thin James had their old house & yard arranged to death within riding a pony - presently they took the present farm June 17-18-19.

Built a log house a very warm winter. Later they added to it - with frame rooms because Dad wanted that when handling the lumber there - the girls could hang up their clothes - & they were used there - actually.

By now we were becoming a large family. We were 9 - 5 of us are living today. Dad enlarged farm to 3/4 in 1918 built a modern house which has power water & well tiled - the youngest son of family remains on it - (the immediate house) he added 1/4 to it - which belonged to an uncle Mr. Naughton side - another brother farms & lives on the other 1/2 which Dad had - The Mr. Naughton farm & which Dopeak has the original dog house on it - Bursting at the seams & sinking into ground - But a Land Mark these farms are 10 miles north of Our 'A' which in early days was known as Troy Station during the earlier yrs. Mother made trips back east up to 1914 when her mother died - & could never return home to Our 'A' fast enough each time. She wouldn't have lived in East for all the apples in the orchard - Dad would make annual trips back.

My folks helped build our Spring Brook Pres. Church - Mother was a member of the Ladies Aid - & that group did much to furnish it - The minister came weekly from Fort Our 'A' to hold services - At some times they were held
But now we were able to earn a large family.

Reunions - always three yearly household
in the school - until the Church was built -
might mention in passing that during last
25 yrs. The congregation seemed to come from
further west church - & it was decided to move
it in order to be more central - Land had been
found for this purpose - Mother gave this
to the Cause of the Church - which is now
10 miles north of the 'A' at 35 - 8 one mile.
Unfortunately a yr or more ago a new
minister in Fork - declared it impossible
for him to hold services even every second
Sun. out in district - so now those who
wish must go to Fork or the 'A' to attend
Service - It is of course limited now.

In the early days mail was staged
from the 'A' to Fork - & also dropped off at
a point about 8 miles north of the 'A' - known
as Strath Carrol - named for Carrol family.
It was a very old log farm house -
I recall when we were youngsters at
school, the thrill of going to Strath Carrol
after 4 o'clock to get the mail on weekday.
As was to be expected the mail was an
important part of even those early days -
The "Kilnelp Mercury" came into our
home each Wk until I expect the only
familiar thing in it was "Kilnelp Mercury."

Undoubtedly many other folks followed mother & Dad & other pioneers to Our 'Appelle. Dad had a brother who went to the Klondyke & he also was in Calif. & S. during the Gold rush - Later he took up farming near Fort Our 'A. as was known as Nevada Sandy Stewart - He had a young & fine looking nephew with him on farm - who later farmed on his own near reservation west of Fort - He was severely burned in a prairie fire that threatened his farm & house - The horses hitched to a harrow with which they were back firing ran away & were cut by the harrows, same had the shot - & others carried bears forever. Jimmy was spoken as "Robert Jimmy Smith" - He was greatly scarred - & his having floors & burnt - His hands were very scarred - He died same yrs. as in Fort Our 'A.

Travelling in early years was with horses - buggies - wagons - sleighs & cutters I remember. When we got promoted to a beautiful cutter - Red plush tall - even a seat at both for the kids -

Dad had a brother who went to the Florida Keys. He also was in Calif. & S. during the Gold Rush - Later he took up farming near Fort Carson - He had a young time looking after his own herd - who later became one of the best ranchers west of the Missouri River. He was generally buried in a prairie fire that threatened his family. His horses hitched to a harrow and carried away by the tornadoes, games had little chance - they carried near forever.

January was spoken as "Buried Jimmy" - He was greatly admired by others having floors on them. His hands were very frayed - He died around 1945.

Travelling in early years without horses - buggy - wagon - sleighs - cutter - greeves - buggies - blues - etc. Remembered as a beautiful cutter - peak blues - all - a sewer a keen.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
Dad bought our first car in Sept. 1919 - when my eldest son was discharged from army. The car was a "Grey Bird."

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
Had more centers than anyone could imagine. South Butte was Shopping Center.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
Yes - although there are small shopping places at Edgely & Somerton - both near our house. I think folks are inclined to feel at home where their forefathers dealt. So continue to a large degree - so with good roads & modern means of travelling distance isn't great.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
Occasionally once a week if weather permitted.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
My recollection is that it was a regular Saturday trip. Dad always said "I don't want to go but I should." Mother, Dad drove in buggy - usually a team.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
Mother & Dad shopped thru mail order for clothing - groceries were bought in town. Although quantities they'd buy large quantities of staple groceries from Neil Bros. in Wpg. Agents came thru country soliciting orders - rush boxes raisins - dates - prunes - dried apples etc.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
It was just before 1914. I believe in our area it was known as Triplewood Rural Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
Was no shareholder concern. I believe Mother & Dad never entertained much thought of returning east once they came west - Not to go back to live.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Friday or Saturday?

My recollection now is that I was a regular Saturday shopper. Dad always said "I'd rather walk to but I shouldn't."

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? (Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

Mother and Dad shopped primarily for clothing, groceries, and large quantities of supplies necessary for the family. Soliciting agents came - Rural banks, racino, dairies - Purchases - Shipped appeals, etc.

32. When did you first have a telephone and that company provided it?

33. When you came to Sebastian, what was the first thing you did? What was the idea of staying permanently or that you raise up your children after trying it? Then did you make this decision?

I believe my mother had never entertained - until they came to work - Not to go back to live.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

I presume there were a few who left but many others came—
That particular district is more or less a never fail crop area—

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

As you must know there are always some who will strive & struggle—so others who won't—I doubt that any established family left—even in spite of the dirty 30's.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

School board was about only one I can recall—Dad was always very interested in politics—but never connected other than party committees—

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Our town school district—one mile west of house farm was formed built in 1916—& it was my brother D.A. Stewart who suggested Hughesville as a name—that is the name today. He thought fitting at that time to name it after Sir Sam Hughes—my bro. was in the service then—slater severely wounded in right arm—& two yrs. after the arm was amputated above elbow—His only son child was killed in war 2 in the R.C.H.T.

Our family moved from Ohio in 1916-1917.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Dad died at the age of 85 in Sept. 1945. He was present from until that date.

Mother died Feb. 13/55 - at age 89 yrs. She was the last of her family. Dad's two sisters have all passed away.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Better homes - cultivation - The Electric power - good roads - Railroads were among the first. We were 4 1/2 miles from C.N.R. (which was originally G.T.P.)
